Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: US-Native Biomaterials, Nitrogen-functionalized to Adsorb Perchlorate and other Oxyanions from Water

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET-0829092
Cannon


Numerous U.S. groundwater sources host unacceptable levels of perchlorate, nitrate, chromate, vanadate, etc. Available processes for removing these contaminants generally invoke use of petrochemical-based ion exchange media or membranes, which force municipalities and their suppliers to rely on non-renewable raw materials that are mined from non-sustainable and uncertain sources. The investigators are targeting to devise means of employing instead lignocellulosic biomaterials (biocarbons) that originate naturally from within America. The team will build on their recently-devised means of functionalizing the porous biocarbons with reduced-nitrogen groups that remove perchlorate and other oxyanions. The project will link into the Sloan Fellowship program for Minority Ph.D. candidates at Penn State, which is co-led by PI Dr. Cannon. There will also be participation in Penn State's CURO program, which facilitates minority undergraduate research.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
US-Native Biomaterials, Nitrogen-functionalized to Adsorb Perchlorate and other Oxyanions from Water

NSF CBET Environmental Sustainability / GOALI

Grant  0829092

NSF Program Director:  Bruce K. Hamilton

Report Period - StartDate: 10-01-2008 | EndDate: 09-30-2012

 

Dr. Frederick S. Cannon, PI, Pennsylvania State University

Dr. Nicole R. Brown, Co-PI, Pennsylvania State University

Adam Redding, Industrial Co-PI, Siemens Water Technologies

Research Results, Intellectual Merit, and Transformative Impact:  Perchlorate is a contaminant of concern in the U.S. because it is widespread, difficult to treat, and harmful at very low concentrations. Therefore, our goal in this research has been to create low cost, sustainable, and effective perchlorate (ClO4-) removal technologies. The overall hypothesis for our research has been that we can anchor methyl pyridinium functionality (or similar) onto activated carbons; and that this functionality will be well-suited for removing perchlorate and other oxyanions from groundwater. Accordingly, four different tailoring methods have been studied based on this hypothesis.  First, we anchored the pyridiniums onto woody materials (lignocellulosics), with ultimate focus on peach stones.  Second, we grafted pyridinium via a three-step method into four different commercial available granular activated carbons (GAC): coconut, bituminous, hard-wood, and soft-wood. We then electrochemically regenerated several of these so that they could remove more perchlorate.  Third, we anchored quaternary ammonium/epoxide-forming compound (QAE) into the above parent GACs by means of epoxide forming reaction. Finally, we employed polypyrrole-loaded GACs with electrochemical regeneration to remove sulfate.

We found that first, Pyridinium-grafted GAC was able to remove up to 5500 bed volumes (BV) of 30 ppb ClO4- -spiked groundwater to initial breakthrough. In addition, our redox/electrochemical methods have shown to be effective for regeneration of nitrogen tailored activated carbons exhausted after perchlorate removal.

Second, QA-anchoring was performed on both softwood-based and bituminous-based parent carbons. Chemicals with QA and epoxide-forming groups were reacted with hydroxyl substituents on the parent GAC. These reactions were optimized for reaction time, temperature, reactant type, and reactant ratio. Specifically, for the bituminous based carbon, while processing natural groundwater that had been spiked with 30-35 ppb perchlorate, and passing this water through rapid small scale column tests, the bed volumes (BV) to 2 ppb perchlorate breakthrough increased from 870 BV for pristine GAC up to 21,000 BV for the corresponding GAC that had been pre-anchored with QUAB360 (360 Daltons).  However, the wood based GAC that had been anchored with this QUAB360 achieved only 3,000 BV.  None of the QAE leached out of these GACs during the column tests.  The bituminous GAC that had been pre-anchored with QAE hosted more positive surface charge at pH 7.5 than did the wood based QAE-GAC. Per X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, the QAE anchored into the GACs increased their N-content by 1-1.3%.  By means of multiple analyses, the authors surmised that the active quaternary ammonium sites within the tailored bituminous-based GAC were more exposed and thus more accessible for perchlorate adsorption than those within wood based GAC.

The effect of the preparation temperature (T), solution pH (pH) and the dry mass ratio of QAE-to-GAC (R) over the perchlorate adsorption capacity (Qe) were studied by the Response Surface Methodology.  Statistical analysis revealed that the more favorable preparation protocols were: (a) 75?, pH...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: US-Native Biomaterials, Nitrogen-functionalized to Adsorb Perchlorate and other Oxyanions from Water NSF CBET Environmental Sustainability / GOALI Grant 0829092 NSF Program Director: Bruce K. Hamilton Report Period - StartDate: 10-01-2008 | EndDate: 09-30-2012 Dr. Frederick S. Cannon, PI, Pennsylvania State University Dr. Nicole R. Brown, Co-PI, Pennsylvania State University Adam Redding, Industrial Co-PI, Siemens Water Technologies Research Results, Intellectual Merit, and Transformative Impact: Perchlorate is a contaminant of concern in the U.S. because it is widespread, difficult to treat, and harmful at very low concentrations. Therefore, our goal in this research has been to create low cost, sustainable, and effective perchlorate (ClO4-) removal technologies. The overall hypothesis for our research has been that we can anchor methyl pyridinium functionality (or similar) onto activated carbons; and that this functionality will be well-suited for removing perchlorate and other oxyanions from groundwater. Accordingly, four different tailoring methods have been studied based on this hypothesis. First, we anchored the pyridiniums onto woody materials (lignocellulosics), with ultimate focus on peach stones. Second, we grafted pyridinium via a three-step method into four different commercial available granular activated carbons (GAC): coconut, bituminous, hard-wood, and soft-wood. We then electrochemically regenerated several of these so that they could remove more perchlorate. Third, we anchored quaternary ammonium/epoxide-forming compound (QAE) into the above parent GACs by means of epoxide forming reaction. Finally, we employed polypyrrole-loaded GACs with electrochemical regeneration to remove sulfate. We found that first, Pyridinium-grafted GAC was able to remove up to 5500 bed volumes (BV) of 30 ppb ClO4- -spiked groundwater to initial breakthrough. In addition, our redox/electrochemical methods have shown to be effective for regeneration of nitrogen tailored activated carbons exhausted after perchlorate removal. Second, QA-anchoring was performed on both softwood-based and bituminous-based parent carbons. Chemicals with QA and epoxide-forming groups were reacted with hydroxyl substituents on the parent GAC. These reactions were optimized for reaction time, temperature, reactant type, and reactant ratio. Specifically, for the bituminous based carbon, while processing natural groundwater that had been spiked with 30-35 ppb perchlorate, and passing this water through rapid small scale column tests, the bed volumes (BV) to 2 ppb perchlorate breakthrough increased from 870 BV for pristine GAC up to 21,000 BV for the corresponding GAC that had been pre-anchored with QUAB360 (360 Daltons). However, the wood based GAC that had been anchored with this QUAB360 achieved only 3,000 BV. None of the QAE leached out of these GACs during the column tests. The bituminous GAC that had been pre-anchored with QAE hosted more positive surface charge at pH 7.5 than did the wood based QAE-GAC. Per X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, the QAE anchored into the GACs increased their N-content by 1-1.3%. By means of multiple analyses, the authors surmised that the active quaternary ammonium sites within the tailored bituminous-based GAC were more exposed and thus more accessible for perchlorate adsorption than those within wood based GAC. The effect of the preparation temperature (T), solution pH (pH) and the dry mass ratio of QAE-to-GAC (R) over the perchlorate adsorption capacity (Qe) were studied by the Response Surface Methodology. Statistical analysis revealed that the more favorable preparation protocols were: (a) 75?, pH 11 and R of 1.73 g QAE/ g GAC, or (b) 35?, pH 14 and R of 4.00 g QAE/ g GAC. In rapid small scale column test, it was observed that the tailored carbons that were made by means of these two protocols exhibited 18 to 20 times longer bed life than did a Pristine GAC, when processing groundwater that had...
